European Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Two key cabinet members in Britain say a post-Brexit transition would not be a \"back door\" to continued membership in the European Union.\n\n\"There will not be a cliff-edge\" after the UK leaves the EU, said Finance Minister Philip Hammond, who favors a softer, pro-business Brexit, and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, a hardline supporter of Brexit.\n\nIn an article published by The Sunday Telegraph, the two said any transition period would be \"time-limited,\" and that Britain would not have access to the European single market or the customs union after it leaves the bloc.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,\" they wrote.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty -- but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\"\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nThe joint comments by Hammond and Fox came after weeks of clashes over the UK's future outside the bloc.\n\nThe UK is currently due to leave the EU at the end of March 2019 after nearly 52 percent of Britons opted to leave the bloc during the EU referendum in June last year.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May formally triggered the Brexit process on March 29 and divorce negotiations officially began on June 19.\n\nDuring their second round of talks held in July, the EU and UK Brexit teams failed to reach an agreement on 22 of the 44 issues under negotiation.\n\nIn what was due to be published this week, British government ministers planned to set out their aims for the Brexit talks.\n\nAmong the details is one covering the difficult issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland once Britain leaves the EU.\n\nAlso, details of future arrangements including Britain's proposals for a customs agreement with the EU will be released prior to a meeting of the European Council in Brussels in October.\n\nBritain's Brexit Secretary David Davis is due to hold a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels at the end of August.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-03-29", "textEnd": 1529, feuding, two key figures in Britain's cabinet came together Sunday to say any post-Brexit transition would not be a \"back door\" to continued European Union membership.\n\nFinance minister Philip Hammond, who favors a softer, pro-business Brexit, and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, a hard-line supporter of Britain leaving the EU, have clashed over the UK's future outside the bloc.\n\nBut in a joint article for The Sunday Telegraph newspaper, they agreed there should not be a \"cliff-edge\" when Britain leaves in March 2019.\n\nThey said any transition period would be \"time-limited\" and that Brexit would mean Britain pulling out of both the European single market and the customs union.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,\" they wrote.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty -- but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nMeanwhile British government ministers were this week due to start publishing detailed papers setting out their aims for the Brexit talks, with Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative government facing criticism over a perceived lack of clarity about its negotiating position.\n\nThe papers will include one covering the difficult issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland once Britain has left the EU.\n\nAnother batch, to be released ahead of the October meeting of the European Council in Brussels, will examine future arrangements including Britain's proposals for a customs agreement with the EU.\n\nBritain's Brexit Secretary David Davis is due to hold a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels at the end of August.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 552, "textStart": 542}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:49:00Z", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "source": {"uri": "arabnews.com", "title": "Arab News", "id": "4355"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:49:00", "url": "http://www.arabnews.com/node/1143931/world", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8864524", "image": "http://www.arabnews.com/sites/default/files/2017/08/13/969581-1312646052.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:49:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"wiki"}], "body": "Chancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox have come together to declare that a post-Brexit transition would not be a \"back door\" to Britain remaining in the EU.\n\nAfter a summer of cabinet feuding, Mr Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit, and Dr Fox, a hardline Brexiteer, said that they agreed there should not be a \"cliff-edge\" break when Britain leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut in a joint article for The Sunday Telegraph, they agreed that any transition would be \"time limited\" and that Brexit would mean the UK pulling out of both the EU single market and the customs union.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,\" they wrote.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return to Westminster in September.\n\nFrom this week, the Government is to start publishing a new series of detailed papers setting out its negotiating position on a range of key issues, amid criticism from Brussels of a lack of clarity about what it wants from the talks.\n\nThey will start with one covering the thorny issues of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic to be followed in the autumn by a second series looking at the future relationship with the EU, including post-Brexit customs arrangements.\n\nMinisters hope it will be enough to persuade the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier that sufficient progress has been made on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\" to move on to the second phase of talks including a new trade deal.\n\nCopyright (c) Press Association Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "LONDON -- The British government tried to fight back Sunday against criticisms that it is divided and unprepared for Brexit, saying it will set out detailed plans for the U.K.'s exit from the European Union and issuing a joint statement by two Cabinet rivals over Europe.\n\nTrade Secretary Liam Fox, a strong supporter of leaving the European Union, and the more pro-EU Treasury chief Philip Hammond, wrote in the Sunday Telegraph that they agreed there should be a \"time-limited\" transition period after Britain formally leaves the bloc in 2019, to avoid a \"cliff-edge\" for people and businesses.\n\nFox and Hammond said the transition period \"cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\" They didn't say how long the transition would last or what rules would apply during that period.\n\nThe government also said Sunday it wants to increase pressure on the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to settle its outstanding commitments to the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of 3 million EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said that \"with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong U.K. and a strong EU.\"\n\nThe push comes after EU officials expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Davis for a new round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nBritain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. But voters did not rally to her call, leaving May atop a weakened minority government.\n\nIn recent weeks, with May on her summer vacation, members of her Cabinet have openly disagreed about what direction Brexit should take.\n\nOpponents of Brexit have become increasingly vocal, arguing that the public or Parliament must get the chance to vote on any final deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nDavid Miliband, who was foreign minister in Britain's previous Labour government, said leaving the EU was \"an unparalleled act of economic self-harm.\"\n\nWriting in The Observer newspaper, Miliband said there must be \"a straight vote between EU membership and the negotiated alternative.\"\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "United Kingdom withdrawal from the European Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Freedom of movement for workers in the European Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_movement_for_workers_in_the_European_Union", "score": 3, "id": "1271375", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - Britain said on Sunday that it wants talks with the EU to move on to the next phase, as it set out details of the future relationship it wants with the bloc and senior ministers presented a united approach to negotiations.\n\nBritain is keen to start talking about its post-Brexit relationship with Europe, wary of the need to reassure anxious businesses, citizens and investors. But Brussels has insisted that progress must be made on divorce arrangements first.\n\n\"We need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and EU,\" Brexit minister David Davis said in a statement.\n\nBritain's call to move forward with Brexit talks came as finance minister Philip Hammond and trade minister Liam Fox presented a united front that there should be a time-limited transition period - signalling a truce between rival factions in Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet.\n\nDavis's Brexit department said it was preparing to publish several papers, including plans for a new customs arrangement and a proposal on how to resolve the difficulties of a non-physical border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.\n\n\"We've been crystal clear that issues around our withdrawal and our future partnership are inextricably linked,\" a source in Britain's Brexit department said.\n\n\"These papers show we are ready to broaden out the negotiations.\"\n\nTalks so far have focused on how much Britain should pay to leave the EU, what rights British and EU citizens will have, and how to manage a land border to the bloc in Ireland. The two sides will be looking for a solution to those issues at the next round of talks due at the end of this month.\n\nThe decision to announce the publication of papers on its plans indicates Britain's desire to counter criticism from Brussels about its approach to the talks.\n\nIn July, EU officials said progress was difficult not because Britain had unacceptable demands, but because it had no position at all on many issues. EU negotiators have warned that an already-tight timetable could be delayed ahead of a scheduled March 2019 exit.\n\nA British paper focused on \"issues unique to Northern Ireland and Ireland\" is expected ahead of the talks, but no further details of the proposal were provided on Sunday.\n\nThe Sunday Telegraph reported that Britain was seeking a \"Schengen area\" between Britain and Ireland, which would allow free movement of people and a \"light-touch customs regime\" across the border of the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The Brexit department declined to comment on the story.\n\nThe report, which cited an unnamed source in the Brexit department, said that Irish citizens would be able to work freely in the UK, and British citizens would work freely in Ireland. Citizens of other EU countries could access the UK over the Irish border but would not be able to work in Britain without a work permit.\n\nSeparate papers would also address \"Continuity in the availability of goods for the EU and the UK\" and \"Confidentiality and access to official documents\", the Brexit department said.\n\nEager to push talks past the opening divorce issues and on to the future trading and legal ties to the bloc, Britain also promised a series of \"Future Partnership\" papers in the run-up to October's European Council. The first will be a proposal for new customs arrangements.\n\nThe push to move forward with Brexit comes as Prime Minister May's top ministers moved to strike a more united tone on leaving the European Union, after in-fighting in the wake of an electoral failure in June in which May's Conservative party lost its majority in parliament.\n\nSome still dispute her approach, with former foreign minister for the now-opposition Labour party David Miliband and pro-EU Conservative MP Anna Soubry warning in Sunday newspapers of the economic \"self-harm\" of leaving the single market.\n\nHowever, pro-European finance minister Hammond and ardent Brexiteer trade minister Fox set out a joint position in the Sunday Telegraph that a transition period was needed when Britain leaves the EU, but single market membership would still end and the interim period would not be used to stop Brexit.\n\nForeign Minister Boris Johnson said in a tweet that the article was the \"right way forward\" and would \"create certainty and a great new European relationship\".", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 2132, "textStart": 2122}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T11:38:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"uri": "in.reuters.com", "title": "Reuters India", "id": "630"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:38:00", "url": "https://in.reuters.com/article/britain-eu-idINKCN1AT0EC", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8909097", "image": "https://s3.reutersmedia.net/resources/r/?m=02&d=20170813&t=2&i=1196911911&w=&fh=545px&fw=&ll=&pl=&sq=&r=LYNXNPED7C08Q", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "11:38:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"wiki"}], "body": "Britain said on Sunday that it wants talks with the EU to move on to the next phase, as it set out details of the future relationship it wants with the bloc and senior ministers presented a united approach to negotiations.\n\nBritain is keen to start talking about its post-Brexit relationship with Europe, wary of the need to reassure anxious businesses, citizens and investors. But Brussels has insisted that progress must be made on divorce arrangements first.\n\n\"We need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and EU,\" Brexit minister David Davis said in a statement.\n\nBritain's call to move forward with Brexit talks came as finance minister Philip Hammond and trade minister Liam Fox presented a united front that there should be a time-limited transition period - signalling a truce between rival factions in Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet.\n\nDavis's Brexit department said it was preparing to publish several papers, including plans for a new customs arrangement and a proposal on how to resolve the difficulties of a non-physical border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.\n\n\"We've been crystal clear that issues around our withdrawal and our future partnership are inextricably linked,\" a source in Britain's Brexit department said.\n\n\"These papers show we are ready to broaden out the negotiations.\"\n\nTalks so far have focused on how much Britain should pay to leave the EU, what rights British and EU citizens will have, and how to manage a land border to the bloc in Ireland. The two sides will be looking for a solution to those issues at the next round of talks due at the end of this month.\n\nThe decision to announce the publication of papers on its plans indicates Britain's desire to counter criticism from Brussels about its approach to the talks.\n\nIn July, EU officials said progress was difficult not because Britain had unacceptable demands, but because it had no position at all on many issues. EU negotiators have warned that an already-tight timetable could be delayed ahead of a scheduled March 2019 exit.\n\nIRISH SCHENGEN AREA?\n\nA British paper focused on \"issues unique to Northern Ireland and Ireland\" is expected ahead of the talks, but no further details of the proposal were provided on Sunday.\n\nThe Sunday Telegraph reported that Britain was seeking a \"Schengen area\" between Britain and Ireland, which would allow free movement of people and a \"light-touch customs regime\" across the border of the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The Brexit department declined to comment on the story.\n\nThe report, which cited an unnamed source in the Brexit department, said that Irish citizens would be able to work freely in the UK, and British citizens would work freely in Ireland. Citizens of other EU countries could access the UK over the Irish border but would not be able to work in Britain without a work permit.\n\nSeparate papers would also address \"Continuity in the availability of goods for the EU and the UK\" and \"Confidentiality and access to official documents\", the Brexit department said.\n\nEager to push talks past the opening divorce issues and on to the future trading and legal ties to the bloc, Britain also promised a series of \"Future Partnership\" papers in the run-up to October's European Council. The first will be a proposal for new customs arrangements.\n\nThe push to move forward with Brexit comes as Prime Minister May's top ministers moved to strike a more united tone on leaving the European Union, after in-fighting in the wake of an electoral failure in June in which May's Conservative party lost its majority in parliament.\n\nSome still dispute her approach, with former foreign minister for the now-opposition Labour party David Miliband and pro-EU Conservative MP Anna Soubry warning in Sunday newspapers of the economic \"self-harm\" of leaving the single market.\n\nHowever, pro-European finance minister Hammond and ardent Brexiteer trade minister Fox set out a joint position in the Sunday Telegraph that a transition period was needed when Britain leaves the EU, but single market membership would still end and the interim period would not be used to stop Brexit.\n\nForeign Minister Boris Johnson said in a tweet that the article was the \"right way forward\" and would \"create certainty and a great new European relationship\".\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 2113, "textStart": 2103}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T11:55:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"uri": "dnaindia.com", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "id": "492"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:55:00", "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-britain-says-brexit-talks-should-move-to-next-phase-as-ministers-show-unity-2528635", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8910705", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "11:55:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"wiki"}], "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - Britain said on Sunday that it wants talks with the EU to move on to the next phase, as it set out details of the future relationship it wants with the bloc and senior ministers presented a united approach to negotiations.\n\nBritain is keen to start talking about its post-Brexit relationship with Europe, wary of the need to reassure anxious businesses, citizens and investors. But Brussels has insisted that progress must be made on divorce arrangements first.\n\n\"We need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and EU,\" Brexit minister David Davis said in a statement.\n\nBritain's call to move forward with Brexit talks came as finance minister Philip Hammond and trade minister Liam Fox presented a united front that there should be a time-limited transition period - signalling a truce between rival factions in Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet.\n\nDavis's Brexit department said it was preparing to publish several papers, including plans for a new customs arrangement and a proposal on how to resolve the difficulties of a non-physical border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.\n\n\"We've been crystal clear that issues around our withdrawal and our future partnership are inextricably linked,\" a source in Britain's Brexit department said.\n\n\"These papers show we are ready to broaden out the negotiations.\"\n\nTalks so far have focused on how much Britain should pay to leave the EU, what rights British and EU citizens will have, and how to manage a land border to the bloc in Ireland. The two sides will be looking for a solution to those issues at the next round of talks due at the end of this month.\n\nThe decision to announce the publication of papers on its plans indicates Britain's desire to counter criticism from Brussels about its approach to the talks.\n\nIn July, EU officials said progress was difficult not because Britain had unacceptable demands, but because it had no position at all on many issues. EU negotiators have warned that an already-tight timetable could be delayed ahead of a scheduled March 2019 exit.\n\nA British paper focused on \"issues unique to Northern Ireland and Ireland\" is expected ahead of the talks, but no further details of the proposal were provided on Sunday.\n\nThe Sunday Telegraph reported that Britain was seeking a \"Schengen area\" between Britain and Ireland, which would allow free movement of people and a \"light-touch customs regime\" across the border of the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The Brexit department declined to comment on the story.\n\nThe report, which cited an unnamed source in the Brexit department, said that Irish citizens would be able to work freely in the UK, and British citizens would work freely in Ireland. Citizens of other EU countries could access the UK over the Irish border but would not be able to work in Britain without a work permit.\n\nSeparate papers would also address \"Continuity in the availability of goods for the EU and the UK\" and \"Confidentiality and access to official documents\", the Brexit department said.\n\nEager to push talks past the opening divorce issues and on to the future trading and legal ties to the bloc, Britain also promised a series of \"Future Partnership\" papers in the run-up to October's European Council. The first will be a proposal for new customs arrangements.\n\nThe push to move forward with Brexit comes as Prime Minister May's top ministers moved to strike a more united tone on leaving the European Union, after in-fighting in the wake of an electoral failure in June in which May's Conservative party lost its majority in parliament.\n\nSome still dispute her approach, with former foreign minister for the now-opposition Labour party David Miliband and pro-EU Conservative MP Anna Soubry warning in Sunday newspapers of the economic \"self-harm\" of leaving the single market.\n\nHowever, pro-European finance minister Hammond and ardent Brexiteer trade minister Fox set out a joint position in the Sunday Telegraph that a transition period was needed when Britain leaves the EU, but single market membership would still end and the interim period would not be used to stop Brexit.\n\nForeign Minister Boris Johnson said in a tweet that the article was the \"right way forward\" and would \"create certainty and a great new European relationship\".\n\n(Reporting by William James and Alistair Smout; Editing by Alison Williams and Susan Fenton)\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 2132, "textStart": 2122}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T13:35:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"uri": "business-standard.com", "title": "Business Standard", "id": "405"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:35:00", "url": "http://www.business-standard.com/article/reuters/britain-says-brexit-talks-should-move-to-next-phase-as-ministers-show-unity-117081300414_1.html", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8921078", "image": "http://bsmedia.business-standard.com/_media/bs/img/common/no_preview.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "13:35:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"score": 4, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Trade Secretary Liam Fox, a strong supporter of leaving the European Union, and the more pro-EU Treasury chief Philip Hammond, wrote in the Sunday Telegraph that they agreed there should be a \"time-limited\" transition period after Britain formally leaves the bloc in 2019, to avoid a \"cliff-edge\" for people and businesses.\n\nFox and Hammond said the transition period \"cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\" They didn't say how long the transition would last or what rules would apply during that period.\n\nThe government also said Sunday it wants to increase pressure on the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to settle its outstanding commitments to the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of 3 million EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said that \"with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong U.K. and a strong EU.\"\n\nThe push comes after EU officials expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Davis for a new round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nBritain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. But voters did not rally to her call, leaving May atop a weakened minority government.\n\nIn recent weeks, with May on her summer vacation, members of her Cabinet have openly disagreed about what direction Brexit should take.\n\nOpponents of Brexit have become increasingly vocal, arguing that the public or Parliament must get the chance to vote on any final deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nDavid Miliband, who was foreign minister in Britain's previous Labour government, said leaving the EU was \"an unparalleled act of economic self-harm.\"\n\nWriting in The Observer newspaper, Miliband said there must be \"a straight vote between EU membership and the negotiated alternative.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2016-06-", "textEnd": 1990, "textStart": 1981}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T10:33:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"uri": "wsoctv.com", "title": "WSOC", "id": "497"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:33:00", "url": "http://www.wsoctv.com/news/amid-criticism-uk-government-tries-to-show-unity-on-brexit/590103059", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8902514", "image": "https://cmgfeeds.cmgdigital.com/photo/2017/08/13/Belgium_Britain_Brexit_10652_8843446_ver1.0_1280_720.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "10:33:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

British Prime Minister Theresa May (Source: AP Photo) Brexit opponent says two senior UK ministers sympathetic to his plansUK says EU offers restricted post-Brexit residency rights to BritonsIndia submits Vijay Mallya's extradition paperwork to his legal team\n\nThe British government is fighting back against criticism that it is divided and unprepared for Brexit, announcing it will publish a set of detailed proposals on customs arrangements, the status of the Ireland-Northern Ireland border and other issues. The Department for Exiting the European Union said on Sunday that it would release the first set of position papers this week, more than a year after Britons voted in a referendum to leave the European Union. The government says it hopes to persuade the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the UK will have to pay to leave the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nThe exit bill, estimated at tens of billions of euros, is to cover pension liabilities for EU staff and programs Britain committed to funding over the next few years.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\n\"Businesses and citizens in the U.K. and EU want to see the talks progress and move towards discussing a deal that works for both sides,\" the department said in a statement. EU officials have expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Britain's Brexit minister, David Davis, for a new round of negotiations at the end of August. Britain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March. Prime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. But voters did not rally to her call, leaving May atop a weakened minority government.\n\nIn recent weeks, with May on her summer vacation, members of her Cabinet have openly disagreed about what direction Brexit should take.\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Brexit EU Theresa May uk", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-13", "textEnd": 43, "textStart": 28}, {"amb": false, "date": "2016-06-", "textEnd": 2298, "textStart": 2289}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:23:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "title": "The Indian Express", "id": "1155"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:23:00", "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/world/theresa-may-eu-uk-tries-to-parry-claims-its-unprepared-in-brexit-talks-4794449/", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8863279", "image": "http://images.indianexpress.com/2017/06/britain-election_kuma.jpg?w=759", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:23:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"wiki"}], "body": "Prime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit.\n\nChancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox have come together to declare that a post-Brexit transition would not be a \"back door\" to Britain remaining in the EU.\n\nAfter a summer of cabinet feuding, Mr Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit, and Dr Fox, a hardline Brexiteer, said that they agreed there should not be a \"cliff-edge\" break when Britain leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut in a joint article for The Sunday Telegraph, they agreed that any transition would be \"time limited\" and that Brexit would mean the UK pulling out of both the EU single market and the customs union.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,\" they wrote.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return to Westminster in September.\n\nFrom this week, the Government is to start publishing a new series of detailed papers setting out its negotiating position on a range of key issues, amid criticism from Brussels of a lack of clarity about what it wants from the talks.\n\nThey will start with one covering the thorny issues of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic to be followed in the autumn by a second series looking at the future relationship with the EU, including post-Brexit customs arrangements.\n\nMinisters hope it will be enough to persuade the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier that sufficient progress has been made on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\" to move on to the second phase of talks including a new trade deal.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 562, "textStart": 552}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T06:46:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"uri": "home.bt.com", "title": "BT.com", "id": "4082"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:26:00", "url": "http://home.bt.com/news/latest-news/papers-to-outline-governments-aims-ahead-of-brexit-talks-11364203448557", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8907915", "image": "https://home.bt.com/images/britain-will-not-stay-in-eu-by-back-door-say-hammond-and-fox-136420344849410401-170813094018.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "06:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Smout\n\nLONDON, Aug 13 (Reuters) - Britain said on Sunday that it want talks with the EU to move on to the next phase, as it set out details of the future relationship it wants with the bloc and senior ministers presented a united approach to negotiations.\n\nBritain is keen to start talking about its post-Brexit relationship with Europe, wary of the need to reassure anxious businesses, citizens and investors. But Brussels has insisted that progress must be made on divorce arrangements first.\n\n\"We need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and EU,\" Brexit minister David Davis said in a statement.\n\nBritain's call to move forward with Brexit talks came as finance minister Philip Hammond and trade minister Liam Fox presented a united front that there should be a time-limited transition period - signalling a truce between rival factions in Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet.\n\nDavis's Brexit department said it was preparing to publish several papers, including plans for a new customs arrangement and a proposal on how to resolve the difficulties of a non-physical border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.\n\n\"We've been crystal clear that issues around our withdrawal and our future partnership are inextricably linked,\" a source in Britain's Brexit department said.\n\n\"These papers show we are ready to broaden out the negotiations.\"\n\nTalks so far have focused on how much Britain should pay to leave the EU, what rights British and EU citizens will have, and how to manage a land border to the bloc in Ireland. The two sides will be looking for a solution to those issues at the next round of talks due at the end of this month.\n\nThe decision to announce the publication of papers on its plans indicates Britain's desire to counter criticism from Brussels about its approach to the talks.\n\nIn July, EU officials said progress was difficult not because Britain had unacceptable demands, but because it had no position at all on many issues. EU negotiators have warned that an already-tight timetable could be delayed ahead of a scheduled March 2019 exit.\n\nIRISH SCHENGEN AREA?\n\nA British paper focused on \"issues unique to Northern Ireland and Ireland\" is expected ahead of the talks, but no further details of the proposal were provided on Sunday.\n\nThe Sunday Telegraph reported that Britain was seeking a \"Schengen area\" between Britain and Ireland, which would allow free movement of people and a \"light-touch customs regime\" across the border of the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The Brexit department declined to comment on the story.\n\nThe report, which cited an unnamed source in the Brexit department, said that Irish citizens would be able to work freely in the UK, and British citizens would work freely in Ireland. Citizens of other EU countries could access the UK over the Irish border but would not be able to work in Britain without a work permit.\n\nSeparate papers would also address \"Continuity in the availability of goods for the EU and the UK\" and \"Confidentiality and access to official documents\", the Brexit department said.\n\nEager to push talks past the opening divorce issues and on to the future trading and legal ties to the bloc, Britain also promised a series of \"Future Partnership\" papers in the run-up to October's European Council. The first will be a proposal for new customs arrangements.\n\nThe push to move forward with Brexit comes as Prime Minister May's top ministers moved to strike a more united tone on leaving the European Union, after in-fighting in the wake of an electoral failure in June in which May's Conservative party lost its majority in parliament.\n\nSome still dispute her approach, with former foreign minister for the now-opposition Labour party David Miliband and pro-EU Conservative MP Anna Soubry warning in Sunday newspapers of the economic \"self-harm\" of leaving the single market.\n\nHowever, pro-European finance minister Hammond and ardent Brexiteer trade minister Fox set out a joint position in the Sunday Telegraph that a transition period was needed when Britain leaves the EU, but single market membership would still end and the interim period would not be used to stop Brexit.\n\nForeign Minister Boris Johnson said in a tweet that the article was the \"right way forward\" and would \"create certainty and a great new European relationship\". (Reporting by William James and Alistair Smout; Editing by Alison Williams and Susan Fenton)", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-13", "textEnd": 51, "textStart": 45}, {"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 2176, "textStart": 2166}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T11:24:00Z", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:24:00", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4786298/index.html", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8907729", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "11:24:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"wiki"}], "body": "By William James and Alistair Smout\n\nLONDON (Reuters) - Britain said on Sunday that it wants talks with the EU to move on to the next phase, as it set out details of the future relationship it wants with the bloc and senior ministers presented a united approach to negotiations.\n\nBritain is keen to start talking about its post-Brexit relationship with Europe, wary of the need to reassure anxious businesses, citizens and investors. But Brussels has insisted that progress must be made on divorce arrangements first.\n\n\"We need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and EU,\" Brexit minister David Davis said in a statement.\n\nBritain's call to move forward with Brexit talks came as finance minister Philip Hammond and trade minister Liam Fox presented a united front that there should be a time-limited transition period - signalling a truce between rival factions in Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet.\n\nDavis's Brexit department said it was preparing to publish several papers, including plans for a new customs arrangement and a proposal on how to resolve the difficulties of a non-physical border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.\n\n\"We've been crystal clear that issues around our withdrawal and our future partnership are inextricably linked,\" a source in Britain's Brexit department said.\n\n\"These papers show we are ready to broaden out the negotiations.\"\n\nTalks so far have focused on how much Britain should pay to leave the EU, what rights British and EU citizens will have, and how to manage a land border to the bloc in Ireland. The two sides will be looking for a solution to those issues at the next round of talks due at the end of this month.\n\nThe decision to announce the publication of papers on its plans indicates Britain's desire to counter criticism from Brussels about its approach to the talks.\n\nIn July, EU officials said progress was difficult not because Britain had unacceptable demands, but because it had no position at all on many issues. EU negotiators have warned that an already-tight timetable could be delayed ahead of a scheduled March 2019 exit.\n\nIRISH SCHENGEN AREA?\n\nA British paper focused on \"issues unique to Northern Ireland and Ireland\" is expected ahead of the talks, but no further details of the proposal were provided on Sunday.\n\nThe Sunday Telegraph reported that Britain was seeking a \"Schengen area\" between Britain and Ireland, which would allow free movement of people and a \"light-touch customs regime\" across the border of the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The Brexit department declined to comment on the story.\n\nThe report, which cited an unnamed source in the Brexit department, said that Irish citizens would be able to work freely in the UK, and British citizens would work freely in Ireland. Citizens of other EU countries could access the UK over the Irish border but would not be able to work in Britain without a work permit.\n\nSeparate papers would also address \"Continuity in the availability of goods for the EU and the UK\" and \"Confidentiality and access to official documents\", the Brexit department said.\n\nEager to push talks past the opening divorce issues and on to the future trading and legal ties to the bloc, Britain also promised a series of \"Future Partnership\" papers in the run-up to October's European Council. The first will be a proposal for new customs arrangements.\n\nThe push to move forward with Brexit comes as Prime Minister May's top ministers moved to strike a more united tone on leaving the European Union, after in-fighting in the wake of an electoral failure in June in which May's Conservative party lost its majority in parliament.\n\nSome still dispute her approach, with former foreign minister for the now-opposition Labour party David Miliband and pro-EU Conservative MP Anna Soubry warning in Sunday newspapers of the economic \"self-harm\" of leaving the single market.\n\nHowever, pro-European finance minister Hammond and ardent Brexiteer trade minister Fox set out a joint position in the Sunday Telegraph that a transition period was needed when Britain leaves the EU, but single market membership would still end and the interim period would not be used to stop Brexit.\n\nForeign Minister Boris Johnson said in a tweet that the article was the \"right way forward\" and would \"create certainty and a great new European relationship\".\n\n(Reporting by William James and Alistair Smout; Editing by Alison Williams and Susan Fenton)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 2169, "textStart": 2159}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T11:39:00Z", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "title": "The Times of India", "id": "1185"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:39:00", "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/britain-says-brexit-talks-should-move-to-next-phase-as-ministers-show-unity/articleshow/60045471.cms", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8909174", "image": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/photo/msid-47529300/47529300.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "11:39:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

withdrawal from the European Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Philip Hammond and Liam Fox have agreed there should not be a 'cliff-edge' break when Britain leaves the EU in March 2019\n\nChancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox have come together to declare that a post-Brexit transition would not be a \"back door\" to Britain remaining in the EU.\n\nAfter a summer of cabinet feuding, Mr Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit, and Dr Fox, a hardline Brexiteer, said that they agreed there should not be a \"cliff-edge\" break when Britain leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut in a joint article for The Sunday Telegraph, they agreed that any transition would be \"time limited\" and that Brexit would mean the UK pulling out of both the EU single market and the customs union.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,\" they wrote.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return to Westminster in September.\n\nFrom this week, the Government is to start publishing a new series of detailed papers setting out its negotiating position on a range of key issues, amid criticism from Brussels of a lack of clarity about what it wants from the talks.\n\nThey will start with one covering the thorny issues of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic to be followed in the autumn by a second series looking at the future relationship with the EU, including post-Brexit customs arrangements.\n\nMinisters hope it will be enough to persuade the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier that sufficient progress has been made on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\" to move on to the second phase of talks including a new trade deal.\n\nMeanwhile the leading Conservative Remainer Anna Soubry warned the Prime Minister that she needed to face down the \"hard Brexiteers\" in the Conservative ranks if she wanted to hold on to her position in No 10.\n\nIn an article for The Mail on Sunday, the former business minister indicated she could be prepared to join with politicians from other parties to stop the country \"staggering recklessly\" towards a hard break with Brussels.\n\n\"Could I ever see myself joining with like-minded people who want to save our country from such an appalling fate? And has that moment arrived yet?\" she wrote.\n\n\"The answer to the first question is 'it is not impossible'; the answer to the second is 'no'. But I would be betraying my principles if I did not make it clear that country must always come before party.\"\n\nHer comments came as Labour former foreign secretary David Miliband issued a call for politicians on all sides to fight back against the \"worst consequences\" of last year's vote for Britain to leave the EU.\n\nMr Miliband, who narrowly lost out to his brother Ed in the 2010 Labour leadership contest and who now heads the International Rescue Committee relief agency in New York, described the outcome of the 2016 referendum as an \"unparalleled act of economic self-harm\".\n\nWriting in The Observer, he said the country should have the chance to vote on any Brexit deal in a second referendum with a straight choice between remaining in the EU and the negotiated alternative.\n\n\"In Britain, the implementation of the EU referendum decision has been rash and chaotic. The timing and content has been governed by factions in the Tory party. Our negotiating position is a mystery - even on immigration,\" he wrote.\n\n\"So the fightback against the worst consequences of the referendum has the opportunity and responsibility to get its bearings fast.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 121, "textStart": 111, "freq": 2}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T09:39:00Z", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "source": {"uri": "newsandstar.co.uk", "title": "newsandstar.co.uk", "id": "1964"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:39:00", "url": "http://www.newsandstar.co.uk/news/national/article/Britain-will-not-stay-in-EU-by-back-door-say-Hammond-and-Fox-145b4de0-8a5b-4cc3-908f-20dc2eba9d95-ds", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8896975", "image": "http://www.newsandstar.co.uk/image/layout_set_logo?img_id=34305&t=1502617063160", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "09:39:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The British government is fighting back against criticism that it is divided and unprepared for Brexit, announcing it will publish a set of detailed proposals on customs arrangements, the status of the Ireland-Northern Ireland border and other issues.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said on Sunday that it would release the first set of position papers this week, more than a year after Britons voted in a referendum to leave the European Union.\n\nThe government says it hopes to persuade the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to leave the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nThe exit bill, estimated at tens of billions of euros, is to cover pension liabilities for EU staff and programmes Britain committed to funding over the next few years.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\n\"Businesses and citizens in the UK and EU want to see the talks progress and move towards discussing a deal that works for both sides,\" the department said in a statement.\n\nEU officials have expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Britain's Brexit minister, David Davis, for a new round of negotiations at the end of August. Britain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March.\n\nBritain's economy is already a disaster...Brexit is the final nail in the coffin\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "LONDON - The British government tried to fight back Sunday against criticisms that it is divided and unprepared for Brexit, saying it will set out detailed plans for the U.K.'s exit from the European Union and issuing a joint statement by two Cabinet rivals over Europe.\n\nTrade Secretary Liam Fox, a strong supporter of leaving the European Union, and the more pro-EU Treasury chief Philip Hammond, wrote in the Sunday Telegraph that they agreed there should be a \"time-limited\" transition period after Britain formally leaves the bloc in 2019, to avoid a \"cliff-edge\" for people and businesses.\n\nFox and Hammond said the transition period \"cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\" They didn't say how long the transition would last or what rules would apply during that period.\n\nThe government also said Sunday it wants to increase pressure on the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to settle its outstanding commitments to the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of 3 million EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said that \"with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong U.K. and a strong EU.\"\n\nThe push comes after EU officials expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Davis for a new round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nBritain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. But voters did not rally to her call, leaving May atop a weakened minority government.\n\nIn recent weeks, with May on her summer vacation, members of her Cabinet have openly disagreed about what direction Brexit should take.\n\nOpponents of Brexit have become increasingly vocal, arguing that the public or Parliament must get the chance to vote on any final deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nDavid Miliband, who was foreign minister in Britain's previous Labour government, said leaving the EU was \"an unparalleled act of economic self-harm.\"\n\nWriting in The Observer newspaper, Miliband said there must be \"a straight vote between EU membership and the negotiated alternative.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2016-06-", "textEnd": 2262, "textStart": 2253}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T10:12:00Z", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "source": {"uri": "brandonsun.com", "title": "Brandon Sun", "id": "2087"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:12:00", "url": "https://www.brandonsun.com/world/breaking-news/amid-criticism-uk-government-tries-to-show-unity-on-brexit-440136363.html", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8900355", "image": "https://media.brandonsun.com/images/648*432/LON190-717_2017_081606.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "10:12:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"Republic of Ireland\u2013United Kingdom border"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland\u2013United_Kingdom_border", "score": 2, "id": "536741", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": withdrawal from the European Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Chancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox have come together to declare that a post-Brexit transition would not be a \"back door\" to Britain remaining in the EU.\n\nAfter a summer of cabinet feuding, Mr Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit, and Dr Fox, a hardline Brexiteer, said that they agreed there should not be a \"cliff-edge\" break when Britain leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut in a joint article for The Sunday Telegraph, they agreed that any transition would be \"time limited\" and that Brexit would mean the UK pulling out of both the EU single market and the customs union.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,\" they wrote.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return to Westminster in September.\n\nFrom this week, the Government is to start publishing a new series of detailed papers setting out its negotiating position on a range of key issues, amid criticism from Brussels of a lack of clarity about what it wants from the talks.\n\nThey will start with one covering the thorny issues of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic to be followed in the autumn by a second series looking at the future relationship with the EU, including post-Brexit customs arrangements.\n\nMinisters hope it will be enough to persuade the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier that sufficient progress has been made on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\" to move on to the second phase of talks including a new trade deal.\n\nMeanwhile the leading Conservative Remainer Anna Soubry warned the Prime Minister that she needed to face down the \"hard Brexiteers\" in the Conservative ranks if she wanted to hold on to her position in No 10.\n\nIn an article for The Mail on Sunday, the former business minister indicated she could be prepared to join with politicians from other parties to stop the country \"staggering recklessly\" towards a hard break with Brussels.\n\n\"Could I ever see myself joining with like-minded people who want to save our country from such an appalling fate? And has that moment arrived yet?\" she wrote.\n\n\"The answer to the first question is 'it is not impossible'; the answer to the second is 'no'. But I would be betraying my principles if I did not make it clear that country must always come before party.\"\n\nHer comments came as Labour former foreign secretary David Miliband issued a call for politicians on all sides to fight back against the \"worst consequences\" of last year's vote for Britain to leave the EU.\n\nMr Miliband, who narrowly lost out to his brother Ed in the 2010 Labour leadership contest and who now heads the International Rescue Committee relief agency in New York, described the outcome of the 2016 referendum as an \"unparalleled act of economic self-harm\".\n\nWriting in The Observer, he said the country should have the chance to vote on any Brexit deal in a second referendum with a straight choice between remaining in the EU and the negotiated alternative.\n\n\"In Britain, the implementation of the EU referendum decision has been rash and chaotic. The timing and content has been governed by factions in the Tory party. Our negotiating position is a mystery - even on immigration,\" he wrote.\n\n\"So the fightback against the worst consequences of the referendum has the opportunity and responsibility to get its bearings fast.\"\n\nCopyright (c) Press Association Ltd. 2017, All Rights Reserved.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 417, "textStart": 407}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T08:51:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"uri": "derryjournal.com", "title": "derryjournal.com", "id": "1564"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:51:00", "url": "http://www.derryjournal.com/news/ni/britain-will-not-stay-in-eu-by-back-door-say-hammond-and-fox-1-8100640", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8892528", "image": "http://editorial.jpress.co.uk/mastheads/INJF-masthead-share-img.png", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "08:51:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celtic_Britons", "score": 3, "id": "1272812", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "LONDON (AP) -- The British government is fighting back against criticism that it is divided and unprepared for Brexit, announcing it will publish a set of detailed proposals on customs arrangements, the status of the Ireland-Northern Ireland border and other issues.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said Sunday that it would release the first set of position papers this week, more than a year after Britons voted in a referendum to leave the European Union.\n\nThe government says it hopes to persuade the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to leave the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nThe exit bill, estimated at tens of billions of euros, is to cover pension liabilities for EU staff and programs Britain committed to funding over the next few years.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\n\"Businesses and citizens in the U.K. and EU want to see the talks progress and move towards discussing a deal that works for both sides,\" the department said in a statement.\n\nEU officials have expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Britain's Brexit minister, David Davis, for a new round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nBritain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. But voters did not rally to her call, leaving May atop a weakened minority government.\n\nIn recent weeks, with May on her summer vacation, members of her Cabinet have openly disagreed about what direction Brexit should take.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2016-06-", "textEnd": 2003, "textStart": 1994}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T23:15:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"uri": "hosted2.ap.org", "title": "Associated Press", "id": "566"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:41:00", "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-12-APFN-EU--Britain-Brexit/id-fd5ca9a6acd748598c66b11f3109c767", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8854956", "image": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CBImages/?media=photo&contentId=35783e1987e04d708052e9e278eb6db6&fmt=jpg&Role=Preview&reldt=2017-08-12T23:00:52GMT&authToken=eNoFwjESwCAIBMAXMXMIclj4GSOFXcoUPj6ze%2bubYWHZwh0EoOq8z5nWmVY6JFkQ34QkepMa1Zi1Yq%2b4553aLajk0B%2fmkBNX", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "23:15:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Justin Tallis/AFP\n\nLONDON, United Kingdom - After weeks of feuding, two key figures in Britain's cabinet came together Sunday, August 13, to say any post-Brexit transition would not be a \"back door\" to continued European Union membership.\n\nFinance minister Philip Hammond, who favors a softer, pro-business Brexit, and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, a hardline supporter of Britain leaving the EU, have clashed over the UK's future outside the bloc.\n\nBut in a joint article for The Sunday Telegraph newspaper, they agreed there should not be a \"cliff-edge\" when Britain leaves in March 2019.\n\nThey said any transition period would be \"time-limited\" and that Brexit would mean Britain pulling out of both the European single market and the customs union.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,\" they wrote.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nMeanwhile British government ministers were this week due to start publishing detailed papers setting out their aims for the Brexit talks, with Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative government facing criticism over a perceived lack of clarity about its negotiating position.\n\nThe papers will include one covering the difficult issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland once Britain has left the EU.\n\nAnother batch, to be released ahead of the October meeting of the European Council in Brussels, will examine future arrangements including Britain's proposals for a customs agreement with the EU.\n\nBritain's Brexit Secretary David Davis is due to hold a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels at the end of August. - Rappler.com", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2016-06-25", "textEnd": 200, "textStart": 187}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-13", "textEnd": 338, "textStart": 329}, {"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 801, "textStart": 791}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T00:46:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"uri": "rappler.com", "title": "Rappler", "id": "7948"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:26:00", "url": "http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/europe/178557-britain-says-will-not-stay-eu-via-back-door", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8907914", "image": "https://assets.rappler.com/6B60CC5BE8794204A88C2B6425E2CF7E/img/D41FABA08FD64D43B0289EE2AB410986/afp-20160625-uk-london-post-brexit-001.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "00:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}
{"location": null, "categories": [{"label": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "wgt": 100, "id": 140}], "uri": "708773938", "lang": "eng", "title": "Britain will not stay in EU by back door, say Hammond and Fox", "concepts": [], "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/article36026720.ece/02a08/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-369bd278-44ef-442f-af79-1667f9a4fb04_I1.jpg\n\nChancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox have come together to declare that a post-Brexit transition would not be a \"back door\" to Britain remaining in the EU.\n\nAfter a summer of cabinet feuding, Mr Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit, and Dr Fox, a hardline Brexiteer, said that they agreed there should not be a \"cliff-edge\" break when Britain leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut in a joint article for The Sunday Telegraph, they agreed that any transition would be \"time limited\" and that Brexit would mean the UK pulling out of both the EU single market and the customs union.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,\" they wrote.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return to Westminster in September.\n\nFrom this week, the Government is to start publishing a new series of detailed papers setting out its negotiating position on a range of key issues, amid criticism from Brussels of a lack of clarity about what it wants from the talks.\n\nThey will start with one covering the thorny issues of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic to be followed in the autumn by a second series looking at the future relationship with the EU, including post-Brexit customs arrangements.\n\nMinisters hope it will be enough to persuade the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier that sufficient progress has been made on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\" to move on to the second phase of talks including a new trade deal.\n\nMeanwhile the leading Conservative Remainer Anna Soubry warned the Prime Minister that she needed to face down the \"hard Brexiteers\" in the Conservative ranks if she wanted to hold on to her position in No 10.\n\nIn an article for The Mail on Sunday, the former business minister indicated she could be prepared to join with politicians from other parties to stop the country \"staggering recklessly\" towards a hard break with Brussels.\n\n\"Could I ever see myself joining with like-minded people who want to save our country from such an appalling fate? And has that moment arrived yet?\" she wrote.\n\n\"The answer to the first question is 'it is not impossible'; the answer to the second is 'no'. But I would be betraying my principles if I did not make it clear that country must always come before party.\"\n\nHer comments came as Labour former foreign secretary David Miliband issued a call for politicians on all sides to fight back against the \"worst consequences\" of last year's vote for Britain to leave the EU.\n\nMr Miliband, who narrowly lost out to his brother Ed in the 2010 Labour leadership contest and who now heads the International Rescue Committee relief agency in New York, described the outcome of the 2016 referendum as an \"unparalleled act of economic self-harm\".\n\nWriting in The Observer, he said the country should have the chance to vote on any Brexit deal in a second referendum with a straight choice between remaining in the EU and the negotiated alternative.\n\n\"In Britain, the implementation of the EU referendum decision has been rash and chaotic. The timing and content has been governed by factions in the Tory party. Our negotiating position is a mystery - even on immigration,\" he wrote.\n\n\"So the fightback against the worst consequences of the referendum has the opportunity and responsibility to get its bearings fast.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 572, "textStart": 562}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T12:45:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "title": "Belfast Telegraph", "id": "226"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:45:00", "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/britain-will-not-stay-in-eu-by-back-door-say-hammond-and-fox-36026721.html", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8915802", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/article36026720.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/PANews%20BT_P-369bd278-44ef-442f-af79-1667f9a4fb04_I1.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "12:45:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celtic_Britons", "score": 3, "id": "1272812", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "LONDON (AP) -- The British government is fighting back against criticism that it is divided and unprepared for Brexit, announcing it will publish a set of detailed proposals on customs arrangements, the status of the Ireland-Northern Ireland border and other issues.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said Sunday that it would release the first set of position papers this week, more than a year after Britons voted in a referendum to leave the European Union.\n\nThe government says it hopes to persuade the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to leave the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nThe exit bill, estimated at tens of billions of euros, is to cover pension liabilities for EU staff and programs Britain committed to funding over the next few years.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\n\"Businesses and citizens in the U.K. and EU want to see the talks progress and move towards discussing a deal that works for both sides,\" the department said in a statement.\n\nEU officials have expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Britain's Brexit minister, David Davis, for a new round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nBritain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. But voters did not rally to her call, leaving May atop a weakened minority government.\n\nIn recent weeks, with May on her summer vacation, members of her Cabinet have openly disagreed about what direction Brexit should take.\n\nGet news headlines sent daily to your inbox Sign Up!
