"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "LONDON -- The British government is fighting back against criticism that it is divided and unprepared for Brexit, announcing it will publish a set of detailed proposals on customs arrangements, the status of the Ireland-Northern Ireland border and other issues.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said Sunday that it would release the first set of position papers this week, more than a year after Britons voted in a referendum to leave the European Union.\n\nThe government says it hopes to persuade the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to leave the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nThe exit bill, estimated at tens of billions of euros, is to cover pension liabilities for EU staff and programs Britain committed to funding over the next few years.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\n\"Businesses and citizens in the U.K. and EU want to see the talks progress and move towards discussing a deal that works for both sides,\" the department said in a statement.\n\nEU officials have expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Britain's Brexit minister, David Davis, for a new round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nBritain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. But voters did not rally to her call, leaving May atop a weakened minority government.\n\nIn recent weeks, with May on her summer vacation, members of her Cabinet have openly disagreed about what direction Brexit should take.\n\nRelated Items Europe, northern ireland, united kingdom, Western Europe, Ireland government, United Kingdom government, European Union, Michel Barnier, Theresa May, David Davis", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2016-06-", "textEnd": 1998, "textStart": 1989}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T23:39:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"uri": "toledoblade.com", "title": "The Blade", "id": "263"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:39:00", "url": "http://www.toledoblade.com/World/2017/08/12/UK-tries-to-parry-claims-it-s-unprepared-in-Brexit-talks.html", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8854810", "image": "http://www.toledoblade.com/image/2017/08/12/Belgium-Britain-Brexit.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "23:39:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Kingdom withdrawal from the European Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 2, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Britain will leave the European Union by the \"back door\" leaving the single market and customs union in March 2019, Philip Hammond and Liam Fox have jointly declared.\n\nIn an attempt to provide a unified front after a summer of open conflict, the Chancellor and International Trade Secretary have said there will be a transitional \"time-limited\" period designed to avoid a so-called \"cliff-edge\".\n\nHowever, their joint article for the Sunday Telegraph does not declare how long this period will last.\n\nMr Hammond and Mr Fox write: \"We will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation.\n\n\"We will leave the single market, because there was a vote for change on June 23 and that is what we will deliver.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change.\n\n\"That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the single market and outside the customs union and will be a 'third-country' not party to EU treaties.\n\n\"But we are also clear that during this period our borders must continue to operate smoothly; goods bought on the internet must still cross borders; businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU and our innovative, world-leading companies must be able to hire the talent they need, including from within the EU.\"\n\nThe joint statement from those who represent Remain and Leave within the Cabinet comes as Theresa May returns from her walking holiday in Switzerland this week.\n\nMeanwhile, ministers are to publish a new series of detailed papers setting out their aims for the Brexit talks amid criticism about a lack of clarity over the Government's negotiating position.\n\nThese include papers on the issue of the Irish border as well as a paper on the \"future partnership\" arrangements, including the UK's proposals for a new customs agreement with the EU.\n\nThe new detailed proposals come as Mr Davis prepares to embark on a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in the Belgian capital at the end of the month.\n\nMr Barnier has expressed his disappointment that the first two rounds of talks have failed to produce sufficient clarity on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\".\n\nSources at the Department for Exiting the EU said the \"future partnership\" papers would show that the Government is ready to move on to the next stage of the negotiations.\n\nMr Davis said: \"Over the last year, the Government has been working with British businesses and the British people to establish exactly how our new relationship with the EU should look and feel.\n\n\"I've launched this process because with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and a strong EU.\n\n\"It's what businesses across Europe have called on both sides to do and will demonstrate that the UK is ready for the job.\n\n\"As well the issue of the Irish border, the first set of new position papers will also cover continued availability of goods for the EU and the UK, and confidentiality and access to official documents following the UK's withdrawal.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, that it is divided and unprepared for Brexit, announcing it will publish a set of detailed proposals on customs arrangements, the status of the Ireland-Northern Ireland border and other issues.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said Sunday that it would release the first set of position papers this week, more than a year after Britons voted in a referendum to leave the European Union.\n\nThe government says it hopes to persuade the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to leave the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nSponsored Content: Sign up for a free webinar as the U.S. Trade and Development Agency and Small Business Administration explore the hybrid IT environment in government.\n\nThe exit bill, estimated at tens of billions of euros, is to cover pension liabilities for EU staff and programs Britain committed to funding over the next few years.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\n\"Businesses and citizens in the U.K. and EU want to see the talks progress and move towards discussing a deal that works for both sides,\" the department said in a statement.\n\nEU officials have expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Britain's Brexit minister, David Davis, for a new round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nHouse minibus sets stage for fight over sequestration, civilian-defense parity\n\nBritain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The Government will this week set out its negotiating position on key issues\n\nBritain will completely pull out of the EU market and the customs union after Brexit, with no 'back door' option to remain, two opposing Cabinet members have pledged.\n\nAfter a summer of cabinet feuding, Chancellor Philip Hammond, who favours a 'softer' pro-business Brexit, and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, a hardline Brexiteer, appear to have put the differences aside and agree there should not be a 'cliff-edge' break when Britain leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut in a joint article for The Sunday Telegraph, they agreed that any transition would be 'time limited' and that Brexit would mean the UK pulling out of both the EU single market and the customs union.\n\nNo back door: Chancellor Philip Hammond (left), who favours a 'softer' Brexit and hardliner Liam Fox (right) agree that the UK will pull out of both the EU single market and customs union\n\n'We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,' they wrote.\n\n'That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n'We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.'\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return to Westminster in September.\n\nFrom this week, the Government will start publishing a new series of detailed papers setting out its negotiating position on a range of key issues, amid criticism from Brussels of a lack of clarity about what it wants from the talks.\n\nTheresa May will hope the intervention of the two minsters will quieten divisions over Brexit\n\nThey will start with one covering the thorny issues of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic to be followed in the autumn by a second series looking at the future relationship with the EU, including post-Brexit customs arrangements.\n\nMinisters hope it will be enough to persuade the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier that sufficient progress has been made on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's 'divorce bill' to move on to the second phase of talks including a new trade deal.\n\nMeanwhile the leading Conservative Remainer Anna Soubry warned the Prime Minister she needed to face down the 'hard Brexiteers' in the Conservative ranks if she wanted to hold on to her position in No 10.\n\nIn an article for The Mail on Sunday, the former business minister indicated she could be prepared to join with politicians from other parties to stop the country 'staggering recklessly' towards a hard break with Brussels.\n\n'Could I ever see myself joining with like-minded people who want to save our country from such an appalling fate? And has that moment arrived yet?' she wrote.\n\n'The answer to the first question is 'it is not impossible'; the answer to the second is 'no'. But I would be betraying my principles if I did not make it clear that country must always come before party.'\n\nHer comments came as Labour former foreign secretary David Miliband issued a call for politicians on all sides to fight back against the 'worst consequences' of last year's vote for Britain to leave the EU.\n\nMr Miliband, who narrowly lost out to his brother Ed in the 2010 Labour leadership contest and who now heads the International Rescue Committee relief agency in New York, described the outcome of the 2016 referendum as an 'unparalleled act of economic self-harm'.\n\nWarning: Conservative Remainer Anna Soubry has warned the Prime Minister she needs to face down the 'hard Brexiteers' in the Conservative ranks if she wants to hold on to power\n\nWriting in The Observer, he said the country should have the chance to vote on any Brexit deal in a second referendum with a straight choice between remaining in the EU and the negotiated alternative.\n\n'In Britain, the implementation of the EU referendum decision has been rash and chaotic. The timing and content has been governed by factions in the Tory party. Our negotiating position is a mystery - even on immigration,' he wrote.\n\n'So the fightback against the worst consequences of the referendum has the opportunity and responsibility to get its bearings fast.'", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 550, "textStart": 540}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T12:53:00Z", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:53:00", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4786388/index.html", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8916611", "image": "http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2017/08/13/13/4337E31200000578-0-image-a-20_1502627905810.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "12:53:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

position papers this week, more than a year after Britons voted in a referendum to leave the European Union.\n\nThe government says it hopes to persuade the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship that would include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe EU says those negotiations can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to leave the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nThe exit bill, estimated at tens of billions of euros, is to cover pension liabilities for EU staff and programs Britain committed to funding over the next few years.\n\nThe government's Brexit department said Britain wants to show that progress on the preliminary issues has been made and \"we are ready to broaden out the negotiations\" by the time of an EU summit in October.\n\n\"Businesses and citizens in the U.K. and EU want to see the talks progress and move towards discussing a deal that works for both sides,\" the department said in a statement.\n\nEU officials have expressed impatience with the pace of Britain's preparations.\n\nThe bloc's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said last month there was \"a clock ticking\" on the talks. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said last week that Brexit advocates \"already had 14 months\" to issue detailed proposals, but had not.\n\nBarnier is due to meet Britain's Brexit minister, David Davis, for a new round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nBritain voted to leave the EU in June 2016, but did not trigger the formal two-year exit process until March.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May then called a snap election in an attempt to increase her Conservative Party's majority in Parliament and strengthen her negotiating hand. But voters did not rally to her call, leaving May atop a weakened minority government.\n\nIn recent weeks, with May on her summer vacation, members of her Cabinet have openly disagreed about what direction Brexit should take.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2016-06-", "textEnd": 1735, "textStart": 1726}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:58:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"uri": "thegardenisland.com", "title": "Thegardenisland.com", "id": "11517"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:58:00", "url": "http://thegardenisland.com/business/national-and-international/uk-tries-to-parry-claims-it-s-unprepared-in-brexit/article_d5209743-ea89-51f8-ab2b-6996931e03b7.html", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8864975", "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/thegardenisland.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/b6/9b67e135-eecd-58fd-a440-9fc8f1d701bb/598fba6f66d48.image.jpg?resize=512%2C342", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:58:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"type": "wiki"}], "body": "Last month, European Union officials trying to negotiate with the UK over Britain's departure from the bloc complained that progress was difficult because of Britain's unacceptable demands and a lack of any position on many issues.\n\nThe UK Department for Exiting the European Union said Sunday it hoped to persuade the 27 other EU nations to start negotiating a \"deep and special\" future relationship to include a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nBut Brussels negotiators have insisted there are three issues to be sorted before a new relationship can be discussed. The first is how much money the UK will have to pay to leave the bloc, the second addresses whether security checks and customs duties will be imposed at the Irish border and the third deals with the status of EU nationals living in the UK.\n\nEstimates of how much Britain will have to pay to fulfill its obligations from the period of its membership until March 2019 are in the tens of billions of euros range but estimates vary widely among EU and UK politicians and economists.\n\nClarity required\n\n\"Businesses and citizens in the UK and EU want to see the talks progress and move towards discussing a deal that works for both sides,\" the department said in a statement. \"We've been crystal clear that issues around our withdrawal and our future partnership are inextricably linked, and the negotiations so far have reinforced that view,\" a source in Britain's Brexit department told UK newspapers and news agencies.\n\nThe announcement appeared to be an attempt to mask over an apparent lack of unity within the ruling Conservative party on how to proceed with the Brexit.\n\nWriting for the Daily Telegraph, the remain-backing Finance Minister Philip Hammond and the Eurosceptic Trade Minister Liam Fox said Britain would leave the EU in March 2019, there would be a short \"interim period\" to smooth the transition during which Britain would not be party to EU treaties and after that Britain would become fully independent.\n\nThe UK would seek a close partnership with Europe on \"security, trade and commerce\" the ministers wrote. However, there was no indication as to the length of the transition and the overall costs.\n\nNext meeting, new papers\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis is to hold a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, in Brussels at the end of the month. Barnier has expressed concern that the first two rounds have failed to produce clarity on the key issues and that there was \"a clock ticking\" towards the date in 2019 when Britain would be out of the bloc.\n\nThe UK government said it was preparing several papers, including plans for a new customs arrangement and for the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.\n\nThe British ministers also promised a series of papers on their ideas for a \"Future Partnership\" with the EU to be presented in the run-up to October's European Council.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 944, "textStart": 934, "freq": 2}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:45:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"uri": "dw.com", "title": "Deutsche Welle (English)", "id": "430"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:50:00", "url": "http://www.dw.com/en/uk-ministers-to-release-brexit-position-papers-amid-criticism/a-40070725", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8864577", "image": "http://www.dw.com/image/39790537_304.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:45:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Ministers are to publish a new series of detailed papers setting out their aims for the Brexit talks amid criticism about a lack of clarity over the British Government's negotiating position.\n\nThe papers, to be published from this week, will include one covering the thorny issue of the border between Ireland and the North after the UK has left the EU.\n\nA second batch of papers, to be released in the run-up to the October meeting of the European Council in Brussels, will look at \"future partnership\" arrangements, including the UK's proposals for a new customs agreement with the EU.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said the publication of the papers would mark \"an important next step\" towards delivering last year's referendum vote to leave the EU.\n\nThe disclosure comes as Mr Davis prepares to embark on a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in the Belgian capital at the end of August.\n\nMr Barnier is reported to have warned EU ambassadors the first two rounds had failed to produce sufficient clarity on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\".\n\nHis gloomy assessment cast doubt on whether the talks will have made enough progress to begin discussions in the autumn on a new free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nLeo Varadkar meanwhile has expressed his frustration at the failure so far of the UK Government to come up with firm proposals to ensure that there is no return to the \"hard\" border between the North and the Republic.\n\nOn his first official visit to Northern Ireland earlier this month, the Taoiseach even put forward his own suggestions for a \"soft Brexit\" - including the possibility of creating a new EU-UK customs union.\n\nSources at the Department for Exiting the EU said the \"future partnership\" papers would show that the Government is ready to move on to the next stage of the negotiations.\n\nThey insisted the issues of Britain's withdrawal - which include the divorce bill the UK will have to pay in respect of its outstanding liabilities - remained \"inextricably linked\" with the talks on its future relations with the bloc.\n\nMr Davis said: \"Over the last year, the Government has been working with British businesses and the British people to establish exactly how our new relationship with the EU should look and feel.\n\n\"I've launched this process because with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and a strong EU.\n\n\"It's what businesses across Europe have called on both sides to do and will demonstrate that the UK is ready for the job.\n\nAs well the issue of the Irish border, the first set of new position papers will also cover continued availability of goods for the EU and the UK, and confidentiality and access to official documents following the UK's withdrawal.", "extractedDates": null, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The UK will need a transition period to help businesses adjust after Brexit, the chancellor and the international trade secretary have said.\n\nIn a joint Sunday Telegraph article, Philip Hammond and Liam Fox stressed any deal would not be indefinite or a \"back door\" to staying in the EU.\n\nTheir comments are being seen as an attempt to show unity between rival sides in Theresa May's cabinet.\n\nIt comes as ministers start to set out their detailed aims for Brexit.\n\nA series of papers are being published, including one this week covering what will happen to the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after the UK has left the EU.\n\nWriting in the Sunday Telegraph, Mr Hammond and Mr Fox said the UK definitely will leave both the customs union and the single market when it exits the EU in March 2019.\n\nThey said a \"time-limited\" transition period would \"further our national interest and give business greater certainty\" - but warned it would not stop Brexit.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the single market and outside the customs union and will be a 'third-country' not party to EU treaties,\" they said.\n\nThey said the UK's borders \"must continue to operate smoothly\", that goods bought on the internet \"must still cross borders\", and \"businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU\" in the weeks and months after Brexit.\n\nThe two leading politicians said the government wanted to ensure \"there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU\".\n\nBBC political correspondent Ben Wright said Mr Hammond - who is seen to favour a \"softer\" approach to Brexit - and Mr Fox, one of the most prominent pro-Brexit ministers, had \"previously appeared at loggerheads\" over the government's strategy on leaving the EU.\n\nMr Hammond has raised the prospect of a Brexit deal that saw little immediate change on issues such as immigration - something Brexiteers have rejected.\n\nBut our correspondent said their article was an attempt to \"prove cabinet unity on Brexit\".\n\nMeanwhile, former Labour Foreign Secretary David Miliband has called for politicians on all sides to unite to fight back against the \"worst consequences\" of Brexit.\n\nHe described the outcome of last year's referendum as an \"unparalleled act of economic self-harm\".\n\nWriting in the Observer, he said: \"People say we must respect the referendum. We should. But democracy did not end on June 23, 2016.\n\n\"The referendum will be no excuse if the country is driven off a cliff.\"\n\nNegotiations between Brexit Secretary David Davis and EU officials are set to resume at the end of this month.\n\nMr Davis said the publication of the papers outlining the government's aims for Brexit would mark \"an important next step\" towards delivering the referendum vote to leave the EU.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2016-06-23", "textEnd": 2425, "textStart": 2412}, {"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 811, "textStart": 801}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:43:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"uri": "bbc.com", "title": "BBC.com", "id": "489"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:28:00", "url": "http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-40914604", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8879490", "image": "https://ichef-1.bbci.co.uk/news/560/cpsprodpb/3CA1/production/_97312551_54301344-a7e1-4959-a974-1f1b1f2f1326.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:43:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

covering the thorny issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after the UK has left the EU.\n\nA second batch of papers, to be released in the run-up to the October meeting of the European Council in Brussels, will look at \"future partnership\" arrangements, including the UK's proposals for a new customs agreement with the EU.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said the publication of the papers would mark \"an important next step\" towards delivering last year's referendum vote to leave the EU.\n\nThe disclosure comes as Mr Davis prepares to embark on a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in the Belgian capital at the end of August.\n\nMr Barnier is reported to have warned EU ambassadors the first two rounds had failed to produce sufficient clarity on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\".\n\nHis gloomy assessment cast doubt on whether the talks will have made enough progress to begin discussions in the autumn on a new free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nIreland's premier Leo Varadkar meanwhile has expressed his frustration at the failure so far of the UK Government to come up with firm proposals to ensure that there is no return to the \"hard\" border between the North and the Republic.\n\nOn his first official visit to Northern Ireland earlier this month, the Taoiseach even put forward his own suggestions for a \"soft Brexit\" - including the possibility of creating a new EU-UK customs union.\n\nSources at the Department for Exiting the EU said the \"future partnership\" papers would show that the Government is ready to move on to the next stage of the negotiations.\n\nThey insisted the issues of Britain's withdrawal - which include the divorce bill the UK will have to pay in respect of its outstanding liabilities - remained \"inextricably linked\" with the talks on its future relations with the bloc.\n\nMr Davis said: \"Over the last year, the Government has been working with British businesses and the British people to establish exactly how our new relationship with the EU should look and feel.\n\n\"I've launched this process because with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and a strong EU.\n\n\"It's what businesses across Europe have called on both sides to do and will demonstrate that the UK is ready for the job.\n\nAs well the issue of the Irish border, the first set of new position papers will also cover continued availability of goods for the EU and the UK, and confidentiality and access to official documents following the UK's withdrawal.", "extractedDates": null, "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Chancellor Philip Hammond and Brexit Secretary Liam Fox have teamed up to promise the UK will leave the Single Market and the Customs Union, and will not stay in the European Union (EU) via the \"back door\".\n\nThe two men were on different sides of the Brexit debate and have publicly fallen out in recent weeks after Dr. Fox claimed he and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson were not informed of Mr. Hammond's plan to keep the UK tied to the EU for years in a so-called \"transition period\".\n\nMr. Hammond has been widely seen as trying to frustrate or even block Britain's exit from the EU by Brexit supporters.\n\nHowever, the statement, made in an article for The Telegraph, represents a notable change in rhetoric. Both men now appear to be committed to a \"transition period\", but also a \"hard Brexit\", outside of the EU institutions.\n\nThe article's publication comes as the prime minister returns from holiday and ministers prepare to publish papers on Britain's Brexit plans covering the Irish border, the customs union, fisheries, and agriculture over the next 10 days.\n\nIn their article, Mr. Hammond and Dr. Fox write: \"We respect the will of the British people - in March 2019 the United Kingdom will leave the European Union.\n\n\"We will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation.\"\n\nThey pledged the UK will \"leave the single market, because there was a vote for change on June 23rd and that is what we will deliver\".\n\nBrexiteers have been suspicious of a so-called \"transition period\", fearing it would be used to delay leaving the EU and see Brexit drag on until 2022.\n\nIn what seems as an effort to lessen those fears, the ministers write: \"We believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\"\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the single market and outside the customs union and will be a 'third-country' not party to EU treaties, \" they added.\n\n\"But we are also clear that during this period our borders must continue to operate smoothly; goods bought on the internet must still cross borders; businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU and our innovative, world-leading companies must be able to hire the talent they need, including from within the EU.\n\n\"Once the interim period is over, we want a permanent, treaty-based arrangement between the UK and the EU which supports the closest possible relationship with the European Union, retaining close ties of security, trade and commerce.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-06-23", "textEnd": 1467, "textStart": 1458}, {"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 1177, "textStart": 1167}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T10:11:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", "title": "Breitbart", "id": "6627"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:00:00", "url": "http://www.breitbart.com/london/2017/08/13/fox-and-hammond-promise-clean-brexit-customs-union-single-market/", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8923705", "image": "http://media.breitbart.com/media/2016/01/Foreigh-Secretary-Phillip-Hammond-Getty.png", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "10:11:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The UK will need a transition period to help businesses adjust after Brexit, the chancellor and the international trade secretary have said.\n\nIn a joint Sunday Telegraph article, Philip Hammond and Liam Fox stressed any deal would not be indefinite or a \"back door\" to staying in the EU.\n\nTheir comments are being seen as an attempt to show unity between rival sides in Theresa May's cabinet.\n\nIt comes as ministers start to set out their detailed aims for Brexit.\n\nA series of papers are being published, including one this week covering what will happen to the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after the UK has left the EU.\n\nWriting in the Sunday Telegraph, Mr Hammond and Mr Fox said the UK definitely will leave both the customs union and the single market when it exits the EU in March 2019.\n\nThey said a \"time-limited\" transition period would \"further our national interest and give business greater certainty\" - but warned it would not stop Brexit.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the single market and outside the customs union and will be a 'third-country' not party to EU treaties,\" they said.\n\nThey said the UK's borders \"must continue to operate smoothly\", that goods bought on the internet \"must still cross borders\", and \"businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU\" in the weeks and months after Brexit.\n\nThe two leading politicians said the government wanted to ensure \"there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU\".\n\nCabinet unity\n\nBBC political correspondent Ben Wright said Mr Hammond - who is seen to favour a \"softer\" approach to Brexit - and Mr Fox, one of the most prominent pro-Brexit ministers, had \"previously appeared at loggerheads\" over the government's strategy on leaving the EU.\n\nMr Hammond has raised the prospect of a Brexit deal that saw little immediate change on issues such as immigration - something Brexiteers have rejected.\n\nBut our correspondent said their article was an attempt to \"prove cabinet unity on Brexit\".\n\nMeanwhile, former Labour Foreign Secretary David Miliband has called for politicians on all sides to unite to fight back against the \"worst consequences\" of Brexit.\n\nHe described the outcome of last year's referendum as an \"unparalleled act of economic self-harm\".\n\nWriting in the Observer, he said: \"People say we must respect the referendum. We should. But democracy did not end on June 23, 2016.\n\n\"The referendum will be no excuse if the country is driven off a cliff.\"\n\nNegotiations between Brexit Secretary David Davis and EU officials are set to resume at the end of this month.\n\nMr Davis said the publication of the papers outlining the government's aims for Brexit would mark \"an important next step\" towards delivering the referendum vote to leave the EU.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2016-06-23", "textEnd": 2440, "textStart": 2427}, {"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 811, "textStart": 801}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T09:11:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"uri": "citifmonline.com", "title": "citifmonline", "id": "5046"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:11:00", "url": "http://citifmonline.com/2017/08/13/uk-ministers-united-on-brexit-proposals/", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8894363", "image": "http://citifmonline.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/97312551_54301344-a7e1-4959-a974-1f1b1f2f1326.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "09:11:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Ministers are to publish a new series of detailed papers setting out their aims for the Brexit talks amid criticism about a lack of clarity over the Government's negotiating position.\n\nThe papers, to be published from this week, will include one covering the thorny issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after the UK has left the EU.\n\nA second batch of papers, to be released in the run-up to the October meeting of the European Council in Brussels, will look at \"future partnership\" arrangements, including the UK's proposals for a new customs agreement with the EU.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said the publication of the papers would mark \"an important next step\" towards delivering last year's referendum vote to leave the EU.\n\nThe disclosure comes as Mr Davis prepares to embark on a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in the Belgian capital at the end of August.\n\nMr Barnier is reported to have warned EU ambassadors the first two rounds had failed to produce sufficient clarity on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\".\n\nHis gloomy assessment cast doubt on whether the talks will have made enough progress to begin discussions in the autumn on a new free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nIreland's premier Leo Varadkar meanwhile has expressed his frustration at the failure so far of the UK Government to come up with firm proposals to ensure that there is no return to the \"hard\" border between the North and the Republic.\n\nOn his first official visit to Northern Ireland earlier this month, the Taoiseach even put forward his own suggestions for a \"soft Brexit\" - including the possibility of creating a new EU-UK customs union.\n\nSources at the Department for Exiting the EU said the \"future partnership\" papers would show that the Government is ready to move on to the next stage of the negotiations.\n\nThey insisted the issues of Britain's withdrawal - which include the divorce bill the UK will have to pay in respect of its outstanding liabilities - remained \"inextricably linked\" with the talks on its future relations with the bloc.\n\nMr Davis said: \"Over the last year, the Government has been working with British businesses and the British people to establish exactly how our new relationship with the EU should look and feel.\n\n\"I've launched this process because with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and a strong EU.\n\n\"It's what businesses across Europe have called on both sides to do and will demonstrate that the UK is ready for the job.\n\nAs well the issue of the Irish border, the first set of new position papers will also cover continued availability of goods for the EU and the UK, and confidentiality and access to official documents following the UK's withdrawal.\n\nCopyright (c) Press withdrawal from the European Union"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "After a summer of cabinet feuding, Mr Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit, and Dr Fox, a hardline Brexiteer, said that they agreed there should not be a \"cliff-edge\" break when Britain leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nIn a joint article for The Sunday Telegraph, they agreed that any transition would be \"time limited\" and that Brexit would mean the UK pulling out of both the EU single market and the customs union.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time,\" they wrote.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty -- but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nUK Prime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return to Westminster in September.\n\nFrom this week, the UK Government is to start publishing a new series of detailed papers setting out its negotiating position on a range of key issues, amid criticism from Brussels of a lack of clarity about what it wants from the talks.\n\nThey will start with one covering the thorny issues of the Border between Northern Ireland and the Republic to be followed in the autumn by a second series looking at the future relationship with the EU, including post-Brexit customs arrangements.\n\nMinisters hope it will be enough to persuade the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier that sufficient progress has been made on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\" to move on to the second phase of talks including a new trade deal.\n\nMeanwhile the leading Conservative Remainer Anna Soubry warned the prime minister that she needed to face down the \"hard Brexiteers\" in the Conservative ranks if she wanted to hold on to her position in No 10.\n\nIn an article for The Mail on Sunday, the former business minister indicated she could be prepared to join with politicians from other parties to stop the country \"staggering recklessly\" towards a hard break with Brussels.\n\n\"Could I ever see myself joining with like-minded people who want to save our country from such an appalling fate? And has that moment arrived yet?\" she wrote.\n\n\"The answer to the first question is 'it is not impossible'; the answer to the second is 'no'. But I would be betraying my principles if I did not make it clear that country must always come before party.\"\n\nHer comments came as Labour former foreign secretary David Miliband issued a call for politicians on all sides to fight back against the \"worst consequences\" of last year's vote for Britain to leave the EU.\n\nMr Miliband, who narrowly lost out to his brother Ed in the 2010 Labour leadership contest and who now heads the International Rescue Committee relief agency in New York, described the outcome of the 2016 referendum as an \"unparalleled act of economic self-harm\".\n\nWriting in The Observer, he said the country should have the chance to vote on any Brexit deal in a second referendum with a straight choice between remaining in the EU and the negotiated alternative.\n\n\"In Britain, the implementation of the EU referendum decision has been rash and chaotic. The timing and content has been governed by factions in the Tory party. Our negotiating position is a mystery -- even on immigration,\" he wrote.\n\n\"So the fightback against the worst consequences of the referendum has the opportunity and responsibility to get its bearings fast.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 228, "textStart": 218}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T10:22:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "title": "The Irish Times", "id": "1154"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:48:00", "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/uk/uk-ministers-say-brexit-transition-will-not-be-back-door-to-staying-in-eu-1.3185126", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8910018", "image": "https://www.irishtimes.com/polopoly_fs/1.3185125.1502619640!/image/image.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "10:22:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

of open conflict, Hammond and Fox have said there will be a transitional 'time-limited' period designed to avoid a so-called 'cliff-edge'.\n\nHowever, their joint article for the Sunday Telegraph does not declare how long this period will last, Sky News wrote.\n\nHammond and Fox wrote: \"We will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation.\n\n\"We will leave the single market, because there was a vote for change on June 23 and that is what we will deliver.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change.\n\n\"That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty -- but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the single market and outside the customs union and will be a 'third-country' not party to EU treaties.\n\n\"But we are also clear that during this period our borders must continue to operate smoothly; goods bought on the internet must still cross borders; businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU and our innovative, world-leading companies must be able to hire the talent they need, including from within the EU.\"\n\nThe joint statement from those who represent Remain and Leave within the Cabinet comes as Theresa May returns from her walking holiday in Switzerland this week.\n\nMeanwhile, ministers are to publish a new series of detailed papers setting out their aims for the Brexit talks amid criticism about a lack of clarity over the Government's negotiating position.\n\nThese include papers on the issue of the Irish border as well as a paper on the 'future partnership' arrangements, including the UK's proposals for a new customs agreement with the EU.\n\nThe new detailed proposals come as Davis prepares to embark on a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in the Belgian capital at the end of the month.\n\nBarnier has expressed his disappointment that the first two rounds of talks have failed to produce sufficient clarity on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's 'divorce bill'.\n\nSources at the Department for Exiting the EU said the 'future partnership' papers would show that the Government is ready to move on to the next stage of the negotiations.\n\nDavis said: \"Over the last year, the Government has been working with British businesses and the British people to establish exactly how our new relationship with the EU should look and feel.\n\n\"I've launched this process because with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and a strong EU.\n\n\"It's what businesses across Europe have called on both sides to do and will demonstrate that the UK is ready for the job.\n\n\"As well the issue of the Irish border, the first set of new position papers will also cover continued availability of goods for the EU and the UK, and confidentiality and June to allow current immigrants from the EU to retain healthcare, work rights and other benefits that are more generous than those given to migrants from elsewhere. United Kingdom must rescue itself from abrupt Brexit 'disaster': Ex- Conservative Party leader William HagueBrexit transition could last until 2022: UK minister Philip HammondUK consumer morale slips as economic mood hits 4-year low: GfK\n\nThe European Union has proposed that Britons living in the bloc after Brexit will only have the right to stay in the country where they are resident when Britain leaves, Brexit minister David Davis said in a letter on Wednesday.\n\nThe future rights of UK nationals living in the EU and EU nationals living in Britain is one of the issues the bloc wants to settle in the first stage of negotiations. Only then will it move on to talks over the future trading relationship.\n\nIn a letter updating a committee of lawmakers from Britain's upper house of parliament on the negotiations, Davis said the EU was only offering restricted residency rights to Britons.\n\n\"Their offer only guarantees residence rights in the member state in which a British national was resident at the point of our exit from the EU. It does not guarantee the holder ... any right to onward movement within the EU, for example to work or study in a neighbouring member state,\" he said.\n\n\"We have questioned whether this is consistent with the principle of reciprocity, and also with the Commission's desire to protect rights currently enjoyed under EU law. This will be the subject of further discussion in due course.\"\n\nThe European Commission, the Brussels-based executive arm of the EU where a special team is negotiating with London on behalf of the other 27 states, said divorce negotiations should start with addressing the uncertainty caused by Brexit.\n\n\"That includes the financial settlement and the uncertainty that surrounds the rights of EU citizens in the UK and of UK citizens in the EU,\" a spokeswoman said.\n\n\"This should be agreed on the principles of continuity, reciprocity and non-discrimination,\" she said, adding that the triggering of the exit clause by Britain \"does not change the right to free movement\".\n\nShe added: \"Nor should it affect the rights of citizens who have made life choices on the basis of EU law and EU membership.\"\n\nAfter the first full round of talks last month, chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier said there was \"a fundamental divergence\" between the two sides on how to protect the rights of expatriates after Brexit.\n\nBritain set out proposals in June to allow current immigrants from the EU to retain healthcare, work rights and other benefits that are more generous than those given to migrants from elsewhere.\n\nIt said those who had lived in Britain for five years by an as yet unspecified cut-off point could acquire \"settled status\" similar to permanent residency. Those more recently arrived would be allowed to stay until they achieved this status.\n\nThe next round of Brexit talks is due to take place in the last week of August.\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Brexit EU", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-09", "textEnd": 47, "textStart": 33}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-09T16:58:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "title": "The Indian Express", "id": "1155"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:58:00", "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/world/uk-says-eu-offers-restricted-post-brexit-residency-rights-to-britons-4789688/", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8235175", "image": "http://images.indianexpress.com/2017/06/uk-and-brexit-759.jpg?w=759", "date": "2017-08-09", "time": "16:58:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-09"}

October meeting of the European Council in Brussels, will look at \"future partnership\" arrangements, including the UK's proposals for a new customs agreement with the EU.\n\nBrexit Secretary David talks will have made enough progress to begin discussions in the autumn on a new free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nIreland's premier Leo Varadkar meanwhile has expressed his frustration Chancellor Philip Hammond and international trade minister Liam Fox the two key ministers believed to be on opposing ends of Britain's future outside the EU - also said that the UK will not remain in the customs union during the transitional period.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the single market and outside the customs union and will be a 'third-country' not party to EU treaties,\" they wrote.\n\nTheir comments are being seen as an attempt to show unity between rival sides in Prime Minister Theresa May's Cabinet.\n\nThey said the UK's borders \"must continue to operate smoothly\", that goods bought on the Internet \"must still cross borders\", and \"businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU\" in the weeks and months after Brexit.\n\nThe two leading politicians said the government wanted to ensure \"there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU\".\n\nIn their article, Hammond and Fox said: \"We respect the will of the British people in March 2019 the United Kingdom will leave the European Union.\n\n\"We will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation.\n\n\"We will leave the single market, because there was a vote for change on June 23rd and that is what we will deliver.\n\nWe want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\" It comes as ministers start to set out their detailed aims for Brexit. leading Brexiteer, put on a display of unity with a joint pledge that echoes Theresa May's oft-repeated remark that \"Brexit means Brexit\".\n\nWriting in the Brexit-backing Telegraph, the ministers said there would be a \"transition period\" if the UK leaves the 28-country block as expected in March, 2019, to avoid an economic \"cliff edge\" which many businesses and economists fear.\n\nBut they added the transition period would be just that, and would not be used as an attempt to prolong membership or to delay the inevitable.\n\nThe jointly penned article appeared designed to reassure those in favour of a clean break, but will do little to comfort those fearing the consequences of a so-called \"hard Brexit\".\n\n\"We will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation,\" the article said.\n\n\"We will leave the single market, because there was a vote for change on 23 June and that is what we will deliver.\"\n\nIt added that businesses should be assured there would be no \"cliff edge\" despite fears expressed that the UK could crash out of the EU without reaching a deal, which would see UK-EU relations revert to World Trade Organisation rules.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU,\" Mr Hammond and Mr Fox wrote.\n\nMr Hammond had previously ruffled feathers in Brexiteer camp by suggesting he hoped the UK would be able to continue free trade with the EU for as many as four years after leaving.\n\nThe old divisions in the Tory party over Europe appeared to resurface when Mr Fox said that any such transition period would end before the next general election in 2022.\n\nWith Ms May due to return from her summer holiday, the article appeared designed to end party feuding as well as ongoing speculation that the UK might somehow be able to salvage membership of the single market through negotiations with the EU.\n\nOver the coming 10 days, a number of Government papers will be published spelling out the UK's Brexit blueprint on key issues including the customs union, the Irish border, fisheries and agriculture.\n\nFree movement for Irish citizens in and out of Britain is expected to continue after Brexit, with the establishment of a Schengen-style area between Ireland and Britain designed to resolve the border problem.\n\nThe Government has recently moved to clarify that freedom of movement between the EU and the UK will definitely end in 2019, with the three million EU citizens already in Britain having to apply for inclusion on a \"settled status\" register if they wish to remain.\n\nIn June, the EU's Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier called for \"more ambition, clarity and guarantees\" around the protection of EU citizens living in the UK.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": papers setting out their aims for the Brexit talks amid criticism about a lack of clarity over the Government's negotiating position.\n\nThe papers, to be published from this week, will include one covering the thorny issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after the UK has left the EU.\n\nA second batch of papers, to be released in the run-up to the October meeting of the European Council in Brussels, will look at \"future partnership\" arrangements, including the UK's proposals for a new customs agreement with the EU.\n\nEU Chief Brexit Negotiator Michel Barnier at the Irish border. ( Liam McBurney/PA)\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said the publication of the papers would mark \"an important next step\" towards delivering last year's referendum vote to leave the EU.\n\nThe disclosure comes as Mr Davis prepares to embark on a third round of talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in the Belgian capital at the end of August.\n\nMr Barnier is reported to have warned EU ambassadors the first two rounds had failed to produce sufficient clarity on the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\".\n\nHis gloomy assessment cast doubt on whether the talks will have made enough progress to begin discussions in the autumn on a new free trade deal between Britain and the EU.\n\nTaoiseach Leo Varadkar. (Liam McBurney/PA)\n\nIreland's premier Leo Varadkar meanwhile has expressed his frustration at the failure so far of the UK Government to come up with firm proposals to ensure that there is no return to the \"hard\" border between the North and the Republic.\n\nOn his first official visit to Northern Ireland earlier this month, the Taoiseach even put forward his own suggestions for a \"soft Brexit\" - including the possibility of creating a new EU-UK customs union.\n\nSources at the Department for Exiting the EU said the \"future partnership\" papers would show that the Government is ready to move on to the next stage of the negotiations.\n\nThey insisted the issues of Britain's withdrawal - which include the divorce bill the UK will have to pay in respect of its outstanding liabilities - remained \"inextricably linked\" with the talks on its future relations with the bloc.\n\n(Victoria Jones/PA)\n\nMr Davis said: \"Over the last year, the Government has been working with British businesses and the British people to establish exactly how our new relationship with the EU should look and feel.\n\n\"I've launched this process because with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong UK and a strong EU.\n\n\"It's what businesses across Europe have called on both sides to do and will demonstrate that the UK is ready for the job.\n\nAs well the issue of the Irish border, the first set of new position papers will also cover continued availability of goods for the EU and the UK, and confidentiality and access to official documents following the UK's withdrawal.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T05:52:00Z", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:52:00", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4785970/index.html", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8877028", "image": "http://i.dailymail.co.uk/1/2017/08/13/06/wire-1126001-1502603118-955_636x382.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "05:52:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Movement_Directive", "score": 2, "id": "1312290", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - The European Union has proposed that Britons living in the bloc after Brexit will only have the right to stay in the country where they are resident when Britain leaves, Brexit minister David Davis said in a letter on Wednesday.\n\nThe future rights of UK nationals living in the EU and EU nationals living in Britain is one of the issues the bloc wants to settle in the first stage of negotiations. Only then will it move on to talks over the future trading relationship.\n\nIn a letter updating a committee of lawmakers from Britain's upper house of parliament on the negotiations, Davis said the EU was only offering restricted residency rights to Britons.\n\n\"Their offer only guarantees residence rights in the member state in which a British national was resident at the point of our exit from the EU. It does not guarantee the holder ... any right to onward movement within the EU, for example to work or study in a neighbouring member state,\" he said.\n\n\"We have questioned whether this is consistent with the principle of reciprocity, and also with the Commission's desire to protect rights currently enjoyed under EU law. This will be the subject of further discussion in due course.\"\n\nThe European Commission, the Brussels-based executive arm of the EU where a special team is negotiating with London on behalf of the other 27 states, said divorce negotiations should start with addressing the uncertainty caused by Brexit.\n\n\"That includes the financial settlement and the uncertainty that surrounds the rights of EU citizens in the UK and of UK citizens in the EU,\" a spokeswoman said.\n\n\"This should be agreed on the principles of continuity, reciprocity and non-discrimination,\" she said, adding that the triggering of the exit clause by Britain \"does not change the right to free movement\".\n\nShe added: \"Nor should it affect the rights of citizens who have made life choices on the basis of EU law and EU membership.\"\n\nAfter the first full round of talks last month, chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier said there was \"a fundamental divergence\" between the two sides on how to protect the rights of expatriates after Brexit. [nL5N1KB5AO]\n\nBritain set out proposals in June to allow current immigrants from the EU to retain healthcare, work rights and other benefits that are more generous than those given to migrants from elsewhere. [nL8N1JN1G4]\n\nIt said those who had lived in Britain for five years by an as yet unspecified cut-off point could acquire \"settled status\" similar to permanent residency. Those more recently arrived would be allowed to stay until they achieved this status.\n\nThe next round of Brexit talks is due to take place in the last week of August.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-09T18:36:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"uri": "in.reuters.com", "title": "Reuters India", "id": "630"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:36:00", "url": "https://in.reuters.com/article/britain-eu-citizens-idINKBN1AP24L", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8251271", "image": "https://s4.reutersmedia.net/resources/r/?m=02&d=20170809&t=2&i=1196426092&w=&fh=545px&fw=&ll=&pl=&sq=&r=LYNXMPED781IY", "date": "2017-08-09", "time": "18:36:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-09"}

"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union", "score": 5, "id": "1268836", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "London: Two top ministers in the UK Cabinet on Sunday made a public effort to bury their differences over the contours of Brexit, stressing that any deal would not be indefinite or a \"back door\" to staying in the European Union.\n\nIn a joint Sunday Telegraph article, UK chancellor Philip Hammond and international trade minister Liam Fox -- the two key ministers believed to be on opposing ends of Britain's future outside the EU -- also said that the UK will not remain in the customs union during the transitional period.\n\nRepresentational image. Reuters\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the single market and outside the customs union and will be a 'third-country' not a party to EU treaties,\" they wrote.\n\nTheir comments are being seen as an attempt to show unity between rival sides in Prime Minister Theresa May's Cabinet.\n\nThey said the UK's borders \"must continue to operate smoothly\", that goods bought on the internet \"must still cross borders\", and \"businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU\" in the weeks and months after Brexit.\n\nThe two leading politicians said the government wanted to ensure \"there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU\".\n\nIn their article, Hammond and Fox said: \"We respect the will of the British people, in March 2019 the United Kingdom will leave the European Union.\n\n\"We will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation.\n\n\"We will leave the single market, because there was a vote for change on 23rd June and that is what we will deliver. We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty, but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\"\n\nIt comes as ministers start to set out their detailed aims for Brexit. A series of papers are being published, including one this week covering what will happen to the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after the UK has left the EU.\n\nMeanwhile, former labour foreign secretary David Miliband has called for politicians on all sides to unite to fight back against the \"worst consequences\" of Brexit. He described the outcome of last year's referendum as an \"unparalleled act of economic self-harm\".\n\nWriting in the Observer, he said: \"People say we must respect the referendum. We should. But democracy did not end on 23 June last year.\n\n\"The referendum will be no excuse if the country is driven off a cliff.\"\n\nNegotiations between Brexit Secretary David Davis and EU officials are set to resume at the end of this month.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 13, 2017 06:38 pm | Updated Date: Aug 13, 2017 06:38 pm\n\nTags :#Brexit#David davis#David miliband#European union#Newstracker#Northern ireland#Philip hammond#Theresa may", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textEnd": 1595, "amb": false, "date": "2017-06-23", "textStart": 1586, "freq": 2}, {"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-13", "textEnd": 2929, "textStart": 2917, "freq": 2}, {"amb": false, "date": "2019-03-", "textEnd": 1323, "textStart": 1313}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3349185", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T13:28:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "title": "Firstpost", "id": "2530"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:28:00", "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/world/brexit-bill-uk-ministers-put-up-united-front-over-eu-talks-stress-no-deal-will-be-indefinite-3926739.html", "storyUri": "eng-3349185", "id": "8920285", "image": "http://s2.firstpost.in/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Brexit-Britain-EU_AP3.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "13:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}
